title: SPA web UI for bd (local, real-time)
description:
Build a local-first single-page web app for the `bd` (beads) CLI that lets users browse issues, change status, and edit text with real-time updates. The app talks to a local WebSocket server; the server watches `.beads/issues.jsonl` and executes `bd` commands corresponding to edits from the UI.

Scope
- Runs locally; no cloud dependencies
- SPA served from localhost; WebSocket for data
- Live updates driven by `.beads/issues.jsonl` watcher
- Editing in UI sends WS messages; server runs matching `bd` commands

Non-goals
- Multi-user concurrency beyond a single machine
- Authentication/authorization beyond localhost-only protections

Constraints
- ECMAScript modules; JSDoc types; `.ts` only for interface declarations
- Follow provided Coding and Testing Standards
- Prefer minimal dependencies; no heavy framework required
acceptance_criteria:
- User can view issues list and open an issue detail page.
- User can change issue status and edit text fields (title, description, acceptance) from the UI.
- UI changes propagate via WebSocket to a local server; server executes the corresponding `bd` command(s).
- File watcher on `.beads/issues.jsonl` pushes updates; the on-screen issue(s) update without refresh.
- Protocol documented (request/response + push events) with versioning and error model.
- Local-only server binding (127.0.0.1) with basic input validation.
- Tests cover protocol handlers and critical UI flows.
- Quickstart docs explain setup, run, and development workflow.
notes:
Implemented local-first SPA and server with live updates and bd integration.

Highlights
- UI: Issues list and detail views (`app/views/list.js`, `app/views/detail.js`) with status and priority controls plus inline title/description editing; navigation via hash router; app shell in `app/main.js`.
- Protocol: Documented v1.0.0 in `app/protocol.md` and shared symbols via `server/protocol.js`.
- WS transport: Robust client with reconnect and event dispatch (`app/ws.js`); server with request/response and push events, including heartbeat (`server/ws.js`).
- bd integration: Executes matching `bd` commands for list/show/update/edit/dep operations (`server/bd.js`, handlers in `server/ws.js`).
- Live updates: DB watcher broadcasts `issues-changed` and SPA refreshes list/detail accordingly (`server/watcher.js`, `app/main.js`).
- Local-only bind: Defaults to host `127.0.0.1` with configurable port (`server/config.js`).
- Tests: 59 passing tests across app + server covering protocol handlers and critical UI flows (`npm test`).
- Quickstart: Added `docs/quickstart.md` with setup, run, and workflow. DB watching details in `docs/db-watching.md`.

Notes
- The implementation watches the active beads SQLite DB (current beads store) rather than a historical `issues.jsonl`. The doc was updated to reflect this.
- The UI currently supports editing title and description. If acceptance text editing is required, propose a small follow-up to extend the `edit-text` handler and UI.

title: Events: coalesce issues-changed to avoid redundant full refresh
description:
Problem
- Editing an issue triggers two UI refreshes:
  (a) an `issues-changed` event with specific IDs, and then
  (b) a file-watcher-driven `issues-changed` without IDs after the DB file write,
  which causes a full cache refresh.

Impact
- Extra work and flicker; unnecessary network/CPU and slower UX.

Proposal
- Introduce an event coalescer in the UI data layer to merge near-simultaneous events.
- Prefer ID-scoped updates when available and suppress trailing full refreshes that cover the same change window.

Design Sketch
1) Event types
   - `issues-changed:{ids:Set<string>, token?:string, source:'local'|'watcher'|'remote'}`
   - `db-updated:{token?:string}` from the file watcher path (no ids).
2) Coalescing
   - Maintain a sliding window (e.g., 100–200 ms) queue. If an ID-scoped event is received, record its `token` (if any) and changed IDs.
   - If a `db-updated` arrives within the window and its `token` matches or an ID-scoped event was seen, drop or downgrade the full refresh.
   - Otherwise, perform a single full refresh after the window elapses.
3) Source suppression
   - Tag locally-initiated saves with a `token` propagated through to the write and back from the watcher so the UI can distinguish self-originated writes.
4) Safety valve
   - If any error occurs or the ID set is too large, fall back to a full refresh.

Testing
- Unit tests for: only-id updates; watcher-only updates; both within window; mismatched tokens; large ID set fallback.
- Add lightweight logging behind debug flag to verify coalescing in dev.
design:
Server-side authoritative diff emission with optional optimistic UI event.

Overview
- Maintain an in-memory index Map<issue_id, digest> on the server.
- On DB watcher event, debounce 100–200 ms to let writes settle.
- Load current issues, build `next` index using a canonical projection and stable stringify.
- Compute `added`, `removed`, `updated` by comparing `prev` vs `next` (digest via fast non-crypto hash, e.g., xxhash64).
- Emit a single post-commit event: `issues-changed:{ added: string[], updated: string[], removed: string[], rev: string|number, source: 'watcher'|'local'|'remote', token?: string }`.
- Update `prev = next` and bump `rev` (monotonic counter or file ETag/mtime+size).

Local writes
- Option A (simplest): Do not emit immediate UI events on local writes; rely solely on the post-commit diff event.
- Option B (optimistic): Emit immediate `issues-changed:{ids}` with `token`; when the server diff arrives, include the same `token` so the UI can suppress duplicate work.

Safety & fallbacks
- If parsing fails, hashing fails, or the change set exceeds a configured threshold, emit a single `issues-changed:{}` without IDs to signal a full refresh.
- Prefer atomic writes (temp + rename) so the watcher observes finalized state.

A11y/UX impact
- UI still supports coalescing as a thin guard, but should rarely need it once server emits precise diffs.

Scaling notes
- If DB grows large, prefer per-issue `updated_at`/`revision` fields or a server-side change journal to avoid O(N) hashing on every write.
acceptance_criteria:
- A single edit results in exactly one server-emitted `issues-changed` event per DB commit.
- When the edit affects specific issues, the event includes precise `added`, `updated`, and `removed` arrays; the UI applies only incremental updates, with no subsequent full refresh.
- Local writes: either (A) only the server diff is delivered, or (B) an optimistic `{ids, token}` is followed by the server diff that the UI suppresses based on matching `token` or increasing `rev`.
- External/process edits (no token) still produce precise `added/updated/removed` sets.
- Deletions are explicitly included in `removed`, and the UI evicts those issues from cache.
- Rapid consecutive writes coalesce via debounce into one event, and `rev` increases monotonically.
- On parser/read errors or oversized change sets, the server emits a single `issues-changed` without IDs; the UI performs exactly one full refresh.
- Unit tests cover: only-id updates, watcher-only updates, optimistic + server diff, mismatched tokens, large change fallback, and multiple rapid writes.
- Debug logging behind a flag verifies coalescing and emitted payloads during development.
notes:
Implemented UI-side coalescing for `issues-changed` events to suppress redundant full refreshes following targeted (ID-scoped) updates.

Changes
- app/main.js: Added a short suppression window (200 ms) after receiving an ID-scoped `issues-changed`; a trailing watcher-only event within that window is ignored. This preserves immediate responsiveness while avoiding duplicate reloads and flicker.

title: Markdown: support ordered lists using `1)` marker (CommonMark)
description:
The Markdown renderer should recognize ordered list markers using a right parenthesis, per CommonMark. Currently only `1.` is parsed as a list; `1)` renders as plain text.

Context
- CommonMark allows both `1.` and `1)` as ordered list markers.
- Users expect `1)` to start a list just like `1.`.

Change
- Update the Markdown parsing to treat `N)` at the start of a line as an ordered list marker, with the same semantics as `N.`.
- Ensure numbering behavior matches CommonMark (auto-increment when using repeated `1)` etc.).

Notes
- Verify no regressions for code blocks, fenced code, or inline text like "Version 1) beta" that should not start a list.
- If this is a parser configuration gap, prefer configuration over custom hacks.
acceptance_criteria:
- Input starting with `1) ` on a new line begins an ordered list per CommonMark.
- `1) One\n2) Two\n3) Three` renders as an ordered list 1–3.
- `1) One\n1) Two\n1) Three` renders as 1, 2, 3 (auto numbering) if supported by the parser.
- Inline text like `Not a list 1) example` does not start a list.
- Nested lists using `)` markers work: `1) Outer\n   1) Inner` renders correctly.
- Unit tests cover the above cases.
notes: Claimed by agent on 2025-10-25. Will update Markdown parsing to recognize `N)` list markers and add tests per acceptance criteria.

title: Pure push-based issue updates (no fetch)
description: Move beads-ui to a pure push model for issue data. Today clients subscribe to server updates, but use those pushed notifications to trigger a fetch. Goal: Server pushes full issue JSON for `added` and `updated`, and only ids for `removed`. Initial subscribe returns an `added` snapshot with all issues. Client maintains a normalized local cache and re-renders directly from pushed data with no follow-up fetch.
design:
Push-only protocol (breaking):
- Message shape: { topic:"issues", action:"added"|"updated"|"removed", revision:number, snapshot?:boolean, payload:{ issues:Issue[] }|{ ids:string[] } }
- Handshake: Client subscribes with { subscribe:"issues" }; server replies { subscribed:"issues" }.
- Initial subscribe replies with a single `added` snapshot (all issues) and `snapshot:true`.
- Server batches multiple changes into arrays and increments `revision` monotonically per subscription.
- No version negotiation or v1 fallback; fetch-on-notify path removed.

Server:
- For `added`/`updated`, include full Issue JSON; for `removed`, only ids.
- Include `revision` on every message; batch when possible.

Client:
- Maintain normalized store keyed by id; reducers for `added`/`updated`/`removed`.
- Drive UI renders from store; remove issue-list fetch after subscribe.
- Resilience: tolerate out-of-order packets by ignoring stale `revision` (<= last applied).

Compatibility & Rollout:
- Breaking change. No feature flag, no phased rollout, no telemetry collection.
acceptance_criteria:
- After subscribe, there is no network fetch for the issue list in normal operation.
- Server emits full Issue JSON for `added`/`updated` and only ids for `removed`.
- Initial subscribe returns an `added` snapshot with all current issues.

title: SPA web UI for bd (local app)
description:
Purpose: Build a local, single‑page web app to browse issues, change status, and edit text for the bd CLI tracker.

Scope and constraints:
- Backend: Express app in `/server` serving static files from `/app`.
- Realtime: All data exchange via WebSocket using the `ws` package.
- Live updates: Watch `.beads/issues.jsonl`; broadcast changes to the active page/clients.
- Frontend: `index.html` and ES modules in `/app` (vanilla JS, ESM, JSDoc types).
- Actions: Client editing sends WS messages; server maps them to `bd` commands.
- Testing: Use Vitest (Node + jsdom). Configure ESLint/Prettier and type checks via `tsc`.
- Standards: Follow project coding/testing standards provided by user instructions.

High‑level capabilities:
- List, filter, and sort issues.
- View issue details including dependencies.
- Update status and priority; edit title/description.
- Auto‑refresh on `.beads/issues.jsonl` changes; push‑based (no polling).
- Display ready work and basic stats.

Non‑goals (initial phase):
- Multi‑repo orchestration, auth, or remote access beyond localhost.
- Advanced visualization (graphs) beyond simple lists/trees.

WS message types (initial draft):
- `list-issues` { filters }
- `show-issue` { id }
- `update-status` { id, status }
- `edit-text` { id, field: 'title'|'description', value }
- `update-priority` { id, priority }
- `create-issue` { title, type, priority, description }
- `list-ready` {}
- `subscribe-updates` {}

bd command mapping (examples):
- list → `bd list --json [filters]`
- show → `bd show <id> --json`
- update status/priority → `bd update <id> --status ... | --priority ...`
- close → `bd close <id>`; reopen → `bd reopen <id>`
- create → `bd create "title" -t <type> -p <prio> -d "desc"`
- dependencies → `bd dep add|remove <a> <b>`; tree → `bd dep tree <id>` (optional)

Live update source:

title: Fix DB monitoring: watch SQLite DB instead of issues.jsonl
description:
The UI’s file watcher currently monitors `issues.jsonl` for changes. This is incorrect when using the SQLite backend; it should watch the resolved SQLite database file instead. As a result, UI updates are missed or stale when the DB changes.

Follow the same DB resolution order as beads CLI:
1) `--db` flag (e.g., `bd --db /path/to/db.db ...`)
2) `$BEADS_DB` environment variable
3) nearest `.beads/*.db` in current directory or ancestors (walk up like git)
4) `~/.beads/default.db` fallback

Notes:
- Re-resolve and reattach watchers when working directory or configuration changes.
- Handle the case where no DB is found with a clear, actionable message.
acceptance_criteria:
- Watches the resolved SQLite DB file instead of `issues.jsonl`.
- DB path resolution matches beads CLI precedence: `--db` > `$BEADS_DB` > nearest `.beads/*.db` (walk up) > `~/.beads/default.db`.
- Changing the active workspace or `--db` value rebinds the watcher without restart.
- When no DB can be resolved, surfaces a user-facing error with hints to set `--db`, `BEADS_DB`, or initialize with `bd init`.
- Removes any reliance on `issues.jsonl` for change detection in SQLite mode.
- Includes unit tests for resolution logic and watcher rebind behavior.
- Updates documentation to describe the new watching source and resolution order.
notes: Starting implementation: add db resolution per beads precedence (--db > BEADS_DB > nearest .beads/*.db > ~/.beads/default.db), refactor watcher to observe DB file, rebind on config changes, pass --db to bd runner, update tests and docs.

title: Epic: Add `bdui` binary for UI daemon control
description:
Introduce a new CLI binary `bdui` to control the beads-ui server as a background daemon and streamline local usage.

Goals
- Provide `bdui` with commands: `start`, `stop`, `restart`.
- Spawn the UI server as a detached daemon (background process) with PID management.
- On successful `start`, auto-open the app in the OS default browser.
- Cross-platform support (macOS, Linux, Windows)
- Ship as a Node ESM binary, adhering to repo coding standards (JSDoc, ESM, lint/type/test).
- Update docs and add tests.

Notes
- Current server entry: `server/index.js` with Express + WS.
- Package currently `private`; for dev, support `npm link` to expose `bdui` locally.
- Prefer a PID file under a runtime dir (e.g. XDG runtime or OS tmp) to avoid repo writes; include an override via env or flag for debugging.
acceptance_criteria:
- Running `bdui --help` prints usage and lists `start|stop|restart`.
- `bdui start` ensures exactly one detached server instance, writes PID file, and prints the URL.
- `bdui start` opens the default browser to the server URL unless disabled with `--no-open` or `BDUI_NO_OPEN=1`.
- `bdui stop` terminates the daemon gracefully (SIGTERM) and removes the PID file.
- `bdui restart` behaves as `stop` then `start`.
- Exit codes: success=0; not-running on stop=2; invalid command=1.
- Works on macOS and Linux; Windows behavior documented and covered where feasible.
- CI passes: `npm run all` stays green.
notes: Docs updated: README.md and docs/quickstart.md now cover `bdui` usage, flags (`--no-open`), env (`BDUI_RUNTIME_DIR`, `BDUI_NO_OPEN`, `PORT`), and Windows notes. Tests added in UI-99 validate CLI parsing and daemon management. `npm run all` passes locally.

title: bdui: Daemonize server with PID management
description:
Implement background daemon management for the beads-ui server.

Scope
- Start: spawn `node server/index.js` as a detached child; redirect stdio to a log file; unref.
- PID file: write child PID to a runtime directory (prefer `$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/beads-ui` or `os.tmpdir()/beads-ui`), ensure directory exists, and set safe permissions.
- Stop: read PID file, send SIGTERM, wait up to N seconds for clean exit, then SIGKILL as fallback; remove PID file.
- Restart: stop (ignore not-running) then start.
- Idempotency: `start` returns 0 if already running and prints the URL; guard against stale PID files.
- Port/host: respect `server/config.js` defaults and env overrides.
acceptance_criteria:
- `bdui start` leaves no child attached to the invoking terminal and returns 0.
- Log file written under the runtime dir and appended across runs.
- `bdui stop` terminates the daemon and removes the PID file; returns code 2 if not running.
- `bdui restart` performs stop then start and returns 0 on success.
- Stale PID file detection works (no crash), replacing the PID file when necessary.
- Works on macOS and Linux in local testing.
notes: Claiming UI-96. Implementing `bdui` CLI daemon management: start/stop/restart with PID + logs and idempotency. Will integrate as ESM binary per coding standards and respect server/config.js host/port.
